title: Antique Old Style No. 3
content:
At the Cambridge website is offered a KJV Bible

[http://www.cambridge.org/uk/bibles/kjv/standard.htm](http://web.archive.org/web/20080925090715/http:/www.cambridge.org/uk/bibles/kjv/standard.htm "http://www.cambridge.org/uk/bibles/kjv/standard.htm")

featuring a highly interesting old typeface called Antique Old Style No. 3, which has no descenders at all. More precisely, the descenders of f, g, j, p, q, y in Roman and Italic are sqeezed or crippled such that they do not (or almost not) go below the base line enabling extremely non-leaded typesetting.

I uploaded a sample page here

[http://www.sanskritweb.net/temporary/luke.gif](http://web.archive.org/web/20080925090715/http:/www.sanskritweb.net/temporary/luke.gif "http://www.sanskritweb.net/temporary/luke.gif")

It seems to me that this KJV Bible edition, which is a reprint, was originally typeset using the foundry type or hot-metal type of Antique Old Style No. 3, which seems to be a modification of one of the various Bookman fonts.

Question: Is this curious Antique Old Style No. 3 available as a digital font?

 [‹ Alternative(s) to Kingfisher](http://web.archive.org/web/20080925090715/http:/www.typophile.com/node/49778 "Go to previous forum topic") [Looking for complementary font to Arial for WEB ›](http://web.archive.org/web/20080925090715/http:/www.typophile.com/node/49751 "Go to next forum topic")
